exceptions.exn: In environment instr : Set data : Type one_step : instr -> state -> state -> Prop sss_fun : forall (i : instr) (s t1 t2 : state), s ⟬ i ⦒ t1 -> s ⟬ i ⦒ t2 -> t1 = t2 sss_dec : forall (i : instr) (st1 st2 : state), {st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2} + {~ st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2} P : code n : nat st1, st2 : state H : P//st1-[n]->st2 Unable to unify "P//st1-[n]->st2" with "P // st1 ->> st2".

chat.content:
I will give you a Coq proof state, including both hypotheses and a specific goal and your need to prove it. Your response should be a singular code block of Coq proof, without any additional explanation or commentary. Follow to these guidelines:
Introduce variables using unique names to avoid any conflicts.
Keep each command distinct and separated, avoid concatenations like ';' or '[cmd|cmd]'.
Organize your proof with bullets like '-', '+', and '*' instead of braces ({, }). Shift to their double symbols like '--' and '++', when necessary.
Effectively use given premises, follow the syntax and structure demonstrated in the examples provided.

Example 1:

Hypotheses:
n, m: nat
IHn: m + n = n + m

Goal:
m + S n = S n + m

Proof:
```simpl. rewrite <- IHn. auto.```

Example 2:
Hypotheses:

Goal:
forall n m : nat, m + n = n + m

```intros n m. induction n.
- simpl. auto.
- simpl. rewrite <- IHn. auto.```

Sovle This Proof State:

Hypotheses:
instr: Set
data: Type
one_step: instr -> state -> state -> Prop
sss_fun: forall (i : instr) (s t1 t2 : state), s ⟬ i ⦒ t1 -> s ⟬ i ⦒ t2 -> t1 = t2
sss_dec: forall (i : instr) (st1 st2 : state), {st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2} + {~ st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2}
P: code
n: nat
st2: state
st1: state

Goal:
P//st1-[n]->st2 -> P // st1 ->> st2

Premises:

Inductive nat : Set := O : nat | S : nat -> nat Arguments S _%nat_scope
Notation code := (nat * list instr)%type

VectorDef.splitat : forall l r : nat, VectorDef.t ?A (l + r) -> VectorDef.t ?A l * VectorDef.t ?A r where ?A : [instr : Set data : Type one_step : instr -> state -> state -> Prop sss_fun : forall (i : instr) (s t1 t2 : state), s ⟬ i ⦒ t1 -> s ⟬ i ⦒ t2 -> t1 = t2 sss_dec : forall (i : instr) (st1 st2 : state), {st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2} + {~ st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2} P : code n : nat st1 : state st2 : state |- Type]
in_sss_step : forall (k : nat) (l : list instr) (i : instr) (r : list instr) (st1 st2 : state), fst st1 = k + length l -> st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2 -> (k, l ++ i :: r) // st1 :1> st2
sss_step = fun (P : code) (st1 st2 : state) => exists (k : nat) (l : list instr) (i : instr) (r : list instr) (d : data), P = (k, l ++ i :: r) /\ st1 = (k + length l, d) /\ st1 ⟬ i ⦒ st2 : code -> state -> state -> Prop
sss_step_fun : forall (P : code) (s t1 t2 : state), P // s :1> t1 -> P // s :1> t2 -> t1 = t2
sss_step_subcode_inv : forall (P : code) (ii : instr) (st st' : state), (fst st, ii :: nil) <sc P -> P // st :1> st' -> st ⟬ ii ⦒ st'
sss_compute_trans : forall (P : code) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 -> > st2 -> P // st2 -> > st3 -> P // st1 -> > st3
sss_steps_fun : forall (P : code) (k : nat) (s t1 t2 : state), P//s-[k] -> t1 -> P//s-[k] -> t2 -> t1 = t2
sss_progress_compute_trans : forall (P : code) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 -+> st2 -> P // st2 -> > st3 -> P // st1 -+> st3
sss_compute_progress_trans : forall (P : code) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 -> > st2 -> P // st2 -+> st3 -> P // st1 -+> st3
sss_progress_compute : forall (P : code) (st1 st2 : state), P // st1 -+> st2 -> P // st1 -> > st2
sss_steps_sind : forall (P : code) (P0 : nat -> state -> state -> SProp), (forall st : state, P0 0 st st) -> (forall (n : nat) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 :1> st2 -> P//st2-[n]->st3 -> P0 n st2 st3 -> P0 (S n) st1 st3) -> forall (n : nat) (p p0 : state), P//p-[n] -> p0 -> P0 n p p0
sss_steps_ind : forall (P : code) (P0 : nat -> state -> state -> Prop), (forall st : state, P0 0 st st) -> (forall (n : nat) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 :1> st2 -> P//st2-[n]->st3 -> P0 n st2 st3 -> P0 (S n) st1 st3) -> forall (n : nat) (p p0 : state), P//p-[n] -> p0 -> P0 n p p0
Inductive sss_steps (P : code) : nat -> state -> state -> Prop := in_sss_steps_0 : forall st : state, P//st-[0] -> st | in_sss_steps_S : forall (n : nat) (st1 st2 st3 : state), P // st1 :1> st2 -> P//st2-[n] -> st3 -> P//st1-[S n] -> st3 Arguments sss_steps _ _%nat_scope Arguments in_sss_steps_S [P] [n]%nat_scope [st1 st2 st3]
